articles.headline: All Combat Roles Now Open to Women, Defense Secretary Says
articles.snippet: The groundbreaking decision overturns a 1994 Pentagon rule that restricts women from artillery, armor, infantry and other such combat roles.
articles.abstract: The groundbreaking decision overturns a 1994 Pentagon rule that restricts women from artillery, armor, infantry and other such combat roles.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a historic transformation of the American military, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said on Thursday that the Pentagon would open all combat jobs to women.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Dave Philipps

articles.headline: Data Storage on DNA Can Keep It Safe for Centuries
articles.snippet: Scientists have shown that DNA molecules can be the basis for a long-term storage system potentially capable of holding all of the world’s digital information in a tiny space.
articles.abstract: Scientists have shown that DNA molecules can be the basis for a long-term storage system potentially capable of holding all of the world’s digital information in a tiny space.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Computer data has been depicted as microscopic magnetic smudges, electric charges and even Lilliputian patterns of dots that reflect laser beams. It may ultimately move into the fabric of life itself — encoded in the organic molecules that are strung together like pearls to form strands of DNA.

articles.headline: Starbucks Prospers by Keeping Pace With the Coffee Snobs
articles.snippet: Howard Schultz attributes the chain’s recent dazzling performance to the quality of its customers’ experience, and to a newer push toward the high end.
articles.abstract: Howard Schultz attributes the chain’s recent dazzling performance to the quality of its customers’ experience, and to a newer push toward the high end.
articles.lead_paragraph: Angus Maxwell, 27, works in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He describes himself as an “installation and performance artist” and is a member of the Boom! Theater Company. He grew up in Seattle and wears a beard and wire-rim glasses.

articles.headline: In Pennsylvania, a Steel Mill and Its Workers at a Crossroads
articles.snippet: Allegheny Technologies is demanding major concessions from the United Steelworkers, and because the union has balked, the workers have been locked out since August.
articles.abstract: Allegheny Technologies is demanding major concessions from the United Steelworkers, and because the union has balked, the workers have been locked out since August.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRACKENRIDGE, Pa. — For two years, Chris Cummings, a maintenance mechanic, worked 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. six days a week to help prepare for the opening of a gigantic $1.2 billion steel rolling mill that was supposed to bring hundreds of secure, well-paying jobs to the Allegheny River Valley.

articles.headline: Barnes & Noble Wants to Become More Than Books
articles.snippet: The chief executive is leading a push to rebrand Barnes & Noble as more than just a bookstore by expanding its offerings of toys, games and gadgets.
articles.abstract: The chief executive is leading a push to rebrand Barnes & Noble as more than just a bookstore by expanding its offerings of toys, games and gadgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ron Boire was growing up on a dairy farm in upstate New York, helping out around the property for $2 an hour, he saw new books as an out-of-reach luxury.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Wrote Complaints After Firing a Whistle-Blower
articles.snippet: Clients of the broker, Johnny Burris, say a JPMorgan Chase employee wrote the complaints attributed to them and which were filed with the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.
articles.abstract: Clients of the broker, Johnny Burris, say a JPMorgan Chase employee wrote the complaints attributed to them and which were filed with the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnny Burris, a former broker at JPMorgan Chase, might have known he was walking into a minefield when he decided to go public with his concerns about his former employer.

articles.headline: Fear in the Air, Americans Look Over Their Shoulders
articles.snippet: After the latest mass shooting, a wide swath of America’s populace finds itself engulfed in a collective fear, a fear tinged with confusion and exasperation.
articles.abstract: After the latest mass shooting, a wide swath of America’s populace finds itself engulfed in a collective fear, a fear tinged with confusion and exasperation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The killings are happening too often. Bunched too close together. At places you would never imagine.

articles.headline: Robust Jobs Report All but Guarantees Fed Will Raise Rates
articles.snippet: The United States economy added 211,000 jobs in November, and the unemployment rate held at 5 percent, bolstering the case for a central bank interest rate hike.
articles.abstract: The United States economy added 211,000 jobs in November, and the unemployment rate held at 5 percent, bolstering the case for a central bank interest rate hike.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Treating San Bernardino Attack as Terrorism Case
articles.snippet: The shift in the investigation came shortly after officials said the female suspect in the shooting had pledged allegiance to the Islamic State in a Facebook posting.
articles.abstract: The shift in the investigation came shortly after officials said the female suspect in the shooting had pledged allegiance to the Islamic State in a Facebook posting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the day she and her husband killed 14 people and wounded 21 others in San Bernardino, Calif., a woman pledged allegiance to the Islamic State in a Facebook post, officials said Friday, as the F.B.I. announced that it was treating the massacre as an act of terrorism.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Richard Pérez-Peña
